author: Kyle Wiggers
title: Snowflake grows startup accelerator with $200M in new capital - 'TechCrunch
text:
Snowflake grows startup accelerator with $200M in new capital
Quick Summary:
Snowflake plans to expand its startup accelerator with $200 million in additional commitments, the tech giant that specializes in cloud-based data storage said Thursday.
The new injection of capital follows a string of activity by Snowflake over the past several months that illustrates that company‚Äôs growth ambitions.
Earlier this week, the company announced an expanded partnership with Microsoft to offer access to AI models from OpenAI.

author: Estelle Greeff
title: MEC Nonkqubela Pieters hands over spring water protection projects to Zweledinga village
text:
The government is changing people‚Äôs lives for better
Eastern Cape MEC for the department of Rural Development and Agrarian Reform (DRDAR) Nonkqubela Pieters yesterday (subs; 14 February 2024) said the government was bringing change to the people‚Äôs lives so that they could live better.
Speaking during the official handover of spring water protection project constructed by her Department for more than 380 Zweledinga village households in Whittlesea, the MEC stressed that changes made by government were visible.
‚ÄúWhoever says yesterday is same like today might suffering from a poor eyesight, we can get that person spectacles from the Phelophepha train (a government healthcare train).
‚ÄúToday is much different, it‚Äôs spectacular and tomorrow will be much different because things are changing. There was no water in Zweledinga previously but today there‚Äôs water. That means what you don‚Äôt have today, you will get tomorrow,‚Äù Pieters said.
The delivery of spring water protection projects by MEC Pieters marks the completion of infrastructure work done by the Department in a number of rural communities of the Eastern Cape that will now have reliable access to clean fresh water as part of the implementation of the province‚Äôs rural development programme.
She said when the mandate of the then agriculture department was changed to include rural development, government saw a need for developmental programmes like provision of water to support agricultural activities.
‚ÄúThis is meant to develop the farming activities here so that people can become sustainable business people. Farming is business that should be treated as such not something to boost about during traditional ceremonies. People of Zweledinga, you now have enablers, you have the land and water now you must work even harder,‚Äù Pieters said.
She explained that government was not waking people up from their beds and force development but people should take initiatives to be supported. ‚ÄúWe want to see your commitment so that when we intervene and invest so that you can make money,‚Äù she added.
The Department constructed these projects following the announcement by the MEC during the tabling of the Department‚Äôs Policy Speech at the Eastern Cape Legislature, where she announced that R5,3 million was aside for 8 projects across the province.
Because of this investment in water infrastructure rural communities that previously had no access to water will now get access to clean fresh drinking water for consumption and agriculture activities.
DRDAR‚Äôs Rural Appropriation Technology Unit (RATU) implement this project, trains locals to be labourers, procure material for the construction of this project which will now provide access to clean fresh water for Zweledinga villagers, a local school, local farmers producing vegetables and livestock farming who will now have reliable water to irrigate their vegetables and livestock.
During this project about 59 local residents were trained and employed for the rollout of the project, including maintenance when there are challenges with infrastructure.
‚ÄúIn this programme we don‚Äôt have a middleman and spend millions on contractors for something that will not be operational. We employ and train local people and in that way we create opportunities for people to fend for their families,‚Äù said Pieters.
A jubilant resident and farmer, Bukiwe Ntathawe said she was glad that they have access to clean fresh water and she thanked government‚Äôs support.
‚ÄúWe have been battling for a long time for water but our government has heard our pleas hence this assistance. We are now able to produce vegetables like cabbages something that was impossible before and our livestock also have access to water. Our gardens are now flourishing and this water tastes nice as they are not salty like the water from boreholes,‚Äù Ntathawe said.
Another resident, Lwando Sikeyi said he had no words to explain his joy and that of his community.
‚ÄúThe provision of this water has assisted us a lot, we are able to do things that we could not do before. As a farmer, I‚Äôm now producing good crops and vegetables because of I‚Äôm able to irrigate my produce. I am very thankful about what government has done us,‚Äù Sikeyi said, adding that the water tasting ‚Äúgood.‚Äù
In delivering these spring water protection projects DRDAR identifies nearby hills and mountains with spring water, connect infrastructure channeling water to installed communal taps for use by households and 40 taps were installed in Zweledinga.
To date a total of 757 water taps have been installed in 36 villages across the province, benefitting 8 781 households, 4 schools, 1 clinic and 1 youth co-operative
The programme is aligned with food security program in each village as it is meant to support communities to produce their own food.
For more information please contact:
Mvusiwekhaya Sicwetsha (Chief Director Communications and Customer Care Services)
Cell: 082 955 8833

author: mvega@thestar.ca (Manuela Vega)
title: Toronto churches forced to close doors to refugees + Time‚Äôs up for city‚Äôs coin-only parking meters
text:
Good morning. This is the Thursday, Dec. 28 edition of First Up, the Star‚Äôs daily morning digest. Sign up
to get it earlier each day, in your inbox.
Here‚Äôs the latest on the recent spike in labour trafficking prosecutions, the future of Toronto‚Äôs parking meters and Toronto churches‚Äô struggle to shelter refugees.
DON‚ÄôT MISS:
This Mountie helped dismantle a suspected labour trafficking ring ‚Äî now he‚Äôs accused of starting his own
In late 2019, investigators had just dismantled what they alleged was a large labour trafficking ring in the Hamilton area. Officers criminally charged six people under worker exploitation laws after finding as many as 80 foreign workers housed in bug- and vermin-infested conditions, and being sent to work across southern Ontario, police said at the time. Now, police allege RCMP Const. Yahsif Israel Mane Monter learned how the Hamilton trafficking scheme operated ‚Äî and then started his own, Sara Mojtehedzadeh and Rachel Mendleson report.
Here‚Äôs what else police material obtained by the Star reveals.
Wait, what? Monter was arrested in May 2022 on human trafficking and several other charges, including firearm violations and animal cruelty related to his dog-breeding business, ‚ÄúTaskforce Rottweilers.‚Äù
Word from Monter: Monter, who has been released on bail ahead of his scheduled May 2024 trial, declined to comment. His lawyer said he ‚Äúwill be pleading not guilty.‚Äù
Time‚Äôs up for Toronto‚Äôs coin-only parking meters
You might be interested in
In 2000, Toronto had 16,000 coin-only parking meters. Today, only 178 remain ‚Äî but their time is up, David Rider reports. The technological dinosaurs will be gone in the new year in the name of progress and city finances. They could be replaced with pay-and-display boxes, the city‚Äôs new ‚Äúpay by plate‚Äù machines or even a new ‚Äúmobile only‚Äù zones with no device at all.
Here‚Äôs how the relics made their way into the city ‚Äî and why they‚Äôre on their way out.
Wait, what? ‚ÄúWe are collecting, on average, about 18 cents a day at single-space meters that cost about 87 cents a day to operate,‚Äù said Jeff Dea, the Toronto Parking Authority‚Äôs vice-president of business development. ‚ÄúThey are really old, they‚Äôre at the end of their service life, they‚Äôre not running well and require continual maintenance so it‚Äôs time to pull them off the street and replace them with something better.‚Äù
More: Dea said the parking authority‚Äôs modernization plan also foresees the use of cameras to automatically record licence plates and bill the vehicle‚Äôs owner.
Citing dwindling government support, Toronto churches are forced to close their doors to refugees
For nearly six months, volunteers and staff at two Toronto churches have worked overtime to shelter, support and feed hundreds of refugees arriving at their doors. But church leaders have seen the growing toll, from shelter workers experiencing psychological breakdowns to mounting personal credit card debt as the churches wrack up more than $800,000 in bills, Emily Fagan reports. Meanwhile, donations are dwindling and government support is sparse.
Here‚Äôs why one church leader was shocked to hear the government wouldn‚Äôt be helping more.
Word from Toronto: A spokesperson for the city said Toronto is working to support refugee claimants ‚Äî but the absence of $97 million in promised federal funding has been challenging. The city estimates it will have spent $103 million supporting refugees this year, with hopes the federal government reimburses the money.
Word from Ottawa: An Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada spokesperson said minister Marc Miller is in touch with Mayor Olivia Chow to discuss solutions, citing the $7 million asylum seekers reception centre in Peel Region announced last month.
WHAT ELSE:
-
Want to see Doug Ford and Pierre Poilievre lose? Then the left needs to get its act together, Martin Regg Cohn writes.
-
The UN is warning of impeded aid deliveries to Gaza as Israel expands its offensive. Here‚Äôs the latest.
-
Peel police are investigating a potential link between a gold seizure in Montreal and gold heist at Pearson Airport.
-
Donald Trump says he didn‚Äôt know his immigration rhetoric echoes Hitler. That‚Äôs part of a broader pattern.
-
Profits, losses and the bottom line. Here are five Canadian stocks to watch in 2024.
-
When did so many famous faces start looking the same? The look has never been mor e common ‚Äî or achievable.
-
Here‚Äôs what will be trending in cruising in 2024, from the rise of boutique ships to the extra-extra long stay.
POV:
CLOSE-UP:
SOUTHERN GAZA: Palestinian journalists attempt to connect to the internet in Rafah on Wednesday, amid continuing battles between Israel and Hamas. Power cuts have become a fact of life in war-torn Gaza, but embedded SIM cards allow Palestinians to access the internet and stay in touch with loved ones abroad.
Thank you for reading First Up. You can reach me and the First Up team at
Sign up here to get this newsletter in your inbox.

author: laregione.ch
title: A Valencia i morti finora sono 158, in migliaia senz'acqua | laRegione.ch
text:
Spagna A Valencia i morti finora sono 158, in migliaia senz'acqua Continua la ricerca dei dispersi dopo le catastrofiche alluvioni. La regione rester√† parzialmente isolata per almeno 2 settimane Le auto sommerse dalla furia degli elementi (Keystone) 1 novembre 2024 | Ats, a cura di Red.Web A tre giorni dalla catastrofe causata dalla Dana nella regione di Valencia, che ha provocato finora 158 morti, continuano senza sosta le ricerche dei dispersi, il cui numero resta ancora imprecisato.
L'emergenza resta alta dopo che circa 366'000 abitanti di una ventina di municipi sono ancora senza acqua potabile mentre 50'000 sono al buio.
Per la mancanza di acqua a causa delle condotte scoppiate per l'inondazione, in alcuni comuni non √® possibile procedere con la pulizia del fango che nel frattempo si √® seccato. Altri 500 soldati si uniranno oggi agli oltre 1'200 impegnati nell'emergenza nella regione dove √® previsto anche l'arrivo del ministro dell'Interno, Fernando Grande-Marlaska. La priorit√† √® garantire beni di prima necessit√†, come acqua, cibo e medicine, alle popolazioni colpite.
La Comunit√† Valenciana rester√† isolata dai collegamenti ferroviari con Madrid e in parte dalla Catalogna per almeno 2 settimane dopo i danni notevoli alla ferrovia: inoltre, 150 arterie della rete stradale sono devastate, mentre restano interrotti vari tratti dell'autostrada A7 di collegamento con Madrid, con colonne di decine di camion e auto fermi ai margini dell'autostrada.
Al momento sono state recuperate 158 vittime. I medici hanno effettuato le autopsie nell'obitorio allestito in un parcheggio: 15 le persone gi√† identificate. Un secondo obitorio √® stato allestito nella Fiera di Valencia, dove saranno trasferite le altre salme recuperate.
Resta connesso con la tua comunit√† leggendo laRegione: ora siamo anche su Whatsapp! Clicca qui e ricorda di attivare le notifiche üîî dana maltempo valencia

author: NewsBreak Original
title: The warmest December in Middlesex County history
text: The popular image of an idyllic December is one of white Christmases, hot chocolate retreats, snow-capped conifers, and cozy, cold-weather activities. But not every December lives up to those expectations. Most of the continental U.S. will experience its peak winter cold weather in January and February . Officially, winter doesn't even start until Dec. 21. Across the U.S., the average December temperature from 1901-2000 was right above freezing point, at 32.68 F. Yearly temperatures can be compared to this 20th-century long-term average to find how uncommon a year's December climate was. The nation's warmest December on record was 2021, when the average temperature reached 6.66 F above the long-term average, at 39.34 F. December 2022 was closer to the previous century's average for the U.S. overall, at 33.08 F. The average temperature in Middlesex County, Connecticut from 1901-2000 was 30.6. The diverse climates of the U.S. mean residents can experience a range of holiday weather without breaking out their passports. Within the continental U.S., Monroe County, Florida, at the Southeast tip of the state, reported the highest average December temperature during the past century at 67.6 F. On the other end of the spectrum was Roseau County, Minnesota, bordering Canada, at 7.2 F. However, across both sides of the extremes, temperatures are warming. While that doesn't mean every December will be warmer than the last or the prior century's average, it does mean long-term temperature averages will continue to inch up the thermometer. When did Middlesex County, Connecticut experience its warmest December? To find out, Stacker used data from the National Centers for Environmental Information to identify the 15 Decembers with the highest average temperature since 1895. Also included is how that year's temperature compared to the 1901-2000 average. Read on to see if you lived through the warmest December in Middlesex County, Connecticut history.
